overview.short: Spirillum volutans is a large, Gram-negative, aerobic spiral bacterium found in freshwater environments and notable for strong polar flagellar motility.
overview.clinical_context: Not a typical human pathogen; primarily environmental and rarely encountered in clinical diagnostics.

species_markers.notes: Classically strongly motile via polar flagella; supports Spirillum-level identification when spiral morphology is observed.
Non-fermentative profile helps exclude oxidase-positive curved/spiral fermenters.

common_confusions.reason: Both may appear curved/spiral and oxidase positive; Campylobacter is usually microaerophilic and may show different growth temperature characteristics.
Spiral morphology overlap; Helicobacter typically prefers microaerophilic conditions and has different biochemical markers (often urease positive depending on species).

when_to_question_identification: Growth only under microaerophilic conditions suggests Campylobacter/Helicobacter rather than Spirillum volutans.
Any positive carbohydrate fermentation profile argues against S. volutans.
Clinical attribution should be cautious unless supported by strong exposure history and confirmatory identification.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Best practical confirmation of spiral morphology and strong polar motility.
Helps describe non-fermenter profile for documentation and comparison.
Recommended for rare organisms where biochemical identification may be unreliable.
